title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with regulatory requirements. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is recognized as an effective advocate for small businesses, ensuring agency responsiveness and compliance with statutory obligations. The independence of the Office is deemed essential for its effectiveness. The Office of Advocacy ensures agency compliance with statutory obligations and independence is crucial for effective advocacy. Sufficient resources are needed for research on regulations' impact on small businesses, making the Office a valuable adviser to Congress and executive branch agencies. The Office of Advocacy requires adequate resources for researching the impact of regulations on small businesses, making it a valuable advisor to Congress and executive branch agencies. The Office of Advocacy requires resources for researching regulations' impact on small businesses, serving as an advisor to Congress and executive agencies. The Act aims to ensure the Office of Advocacy's independence and financial resources to advocate for small businesses, report to Congress and the President on regulatory issues, and have a separate authorization for appropriations. The Office of Advocacy needs corrective action from the regulatory agency or Congress, separate authorization for appropriations, reporting to the President and Congress on agency compliance, and an enhanced role as per chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. OFFICE OF ADVOCACY. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section for the Office of Advocacy. The Office of Advocacy, established under the Small Business Act, includes the Chief Counsel for Advocacy appointed by the President from civilian life with Senate approval. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy is appointed by the President from civilian life with Senate approval, without political affiliation, based on fitness for the role. The appointee cannot have been an officer or employee of the Small Business Administration in the 5 years prior to appointment and can be removed by the President with notification to Congress 30 days in advance. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy in the Small Business Administration can be appointed by the President from civilian life, without political affiliation, and must not have been affiliated with the Administration in the 5 years prior. The President can remove the Chief Counsel with notification to Congress 30 days in advance. The Office's primary functions include examining the role of small businesses in the US economy and their contribution to competition, economic and social mobility, and inflation control. Each appropriation request by the Administration must include a separate request for the Office. The Office's primary functions include examining the role of small businesses in the US economy, assessing Federal subsidy programs, and promoting innovation and entrepreneurship. The Office examines the role of small businesses in the US economy, assesses Federal subsidy programs, and promotes innovation and entrepreneurship. It also evaluates the effectiveness of subsidy programs for small businesses, measures the impact of government regulation, and proposes changes to the tax structure to support small businesses. The Office evaluates the impact of government demands on credit for small businesses, recommends methods for financial resource availability, and suggests ways to deliver financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises. The Office recommends methods for delivering financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises, generating markets, providing business education, management assistance, and compliance support. It evaluates Federal and private sector efforts, makes recommendations to strengthen small businesses, and suggests specific measures for creating an inclusive business environment. The Office evaluates Federal and private sector efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, makes recommendations to strengthen small businesses, and suggests specific measures for creating an inclusive business environment. It also considers developing rational criteria to define small businesses. The Office evaluates efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, recommends measures to strengthen small businesses, and considers developing criteria to define small businesses. It also serves as a focal point for receiving complaints and suggestions regarding policies. The Office serves as a focal point for complaints, criticisms, and suggestions regarding small businesses and government policies. It also counsels small businesses on resolving issues with the Federal Government and proposes changes to improve small business support. The Office resolves issues between small businesses and the Federal Government, proposes policy changes, advocates for small businesses, and collaborates with other agencies to promote government programs for small businesses. The Office assists in disseminating information about Federal Government programs for small businesses and appoints necessary personnel to carry out its duties. The Chief Counsel can appoint and terminate additional personnel as needed for the Office to perform its duties, with the authority to set their compensation up to a maximum rate of GS-15. The Chief Counsel has the authority to set compensation rates for Office personnel, not exceeding the maximum rate of GS-15. Additionally, the Chief Counsel can procure temporary services and consult with experts in various fields as needed. The Chief Counsel can consult with experts in small business investment, venture capital, banking, and other financial institutions. They can also seek advice from individuals with regulatory, legal, economic, or financial expertise, including members of the academic community and those representing the public interest. Additionally, they can utilize the National Advisory Council's services. The Chief Counsel can consult experts in small business investment, venture capital, banking, and financial institutions. They may also seek advice from individuals with regulatory, legal, economic, or financial expertise, including members of the academic community and those representing the public interest. Additionally, they can utilize the National Advisory Council's services and appoint advisory boards or committees as necessary. The Administrator will provide the Office with appropriate office space. The Chief Counsel may hold hearings and gather information from federal agencies as needed. The Administrator will provide the Office with necessary office space, equipment, and maintenance services. The Chief Counsel may obtain information from federal agencies and submit annual reports on agency compliance to relevant committees. The Chief Counsel submits annual reports on agency compliance to relevant committees, including the Small Business of the Senate and the House of Representatives, the Committee on Governmental Affairs of the Senate, the Committee on Government Reform of the House of Representatives, and the Committees on the Judiciary of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Chief Counsel may also prepare additional reports as deemed appropriate, with a prohibition on submitting reports to the Office of Management and Budget or any other federal department before submission to the President and Congress. The Chief Counsel submits reports on agency compliance to relevant committees, with a prohibition on submitting reports to the Office of Management and Budget or any other federal department before submission to the President and Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Office to carry out its duties. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed, and the incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy at the Small Business Administration is specified. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy at the Small Business Administration will continue in their position as per the amended section 32 of the Small Business Act. Appropriated funds will remain available indefinitely, and Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed. The Senate passed the bill on November 5, 1999, as attested by Secretary Gary Sisco.
